ins.il: plural in form but singular or plural in construction

dt: {bc}a servant who shines shoes especially in a hotel

shortdef: a servant who shines shoes especially in a hotel

et: Middle English {it}boten{/it} "to cure, relieve, add to equalize the value of things exchanged, be of use, avail," probably in part derivative of {it}bot, bote{/it} "advantage, good, relief," in part going back to Old English {it}botian{/it} "to recover from ill health, keep in repair," derivative of {it}bōt{/it} "a making good, repair, relief" {ma}{mat|boot:1|}{/ma}

dt: {bc}a fitted covering (as of leather or rubber) for the foot that usually reaches above the ankle
{bc}an instrument of torture used to crush the leg and foot
{bc}something that resembles or is likened to a boot
{bc}an enclosing or protective casing or sheath (as for a rifle or over an electrical or mechanical connection)
{bc}a navy or marine corps recruit undergoing basic training

dt.t: got a big {wi}boot{/wi} out of the joke

dt: {bc}the act of booting or rebooting a computer or the process by which a computer is booted {dx}see {dxt|boot:4||5b}{/dx}

dt.t: A cold {wi}boot{/wi} is starting up a computer whose power has been turned off. A warm {wi}boot{/wi} involves restarting the system while it is running …

et: (senses 1-8) Middle English {it}bote, bot, boot,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}bote{/it} (also continental Old French {it}bote, botte{/it}), of uncertain origin; (sense 9) noun derivative of {et_link|boot:4|boot:4}, sense 5

The French word is traced to a putative Germanic base {it}*butt-{/it} "blunt" in {it}Französisches etymologisches Wörterbuch,{/it} along with a diverse group of phonetically similar words, but both the semantic and phonetic assumptions are questionable.
shortdef: a fitted covering (as of leather or rubber) for the foot that usually reaches above the ankle
an instrument of torture used to crush the leg and foot
something that resembles or is likened to a boot; especially : an enclosing or protective casing or sheath (as for a rifle or over an electrical or mechanical connection)

dt: {bc}to make an error on (a grounder in baseball)
{bc}to load (a program) into a computer from a disk
{bc}to start or ready for use especially by {a_link|booting} a program
{bc}to become loaded into a computer's memory from a disk
{bc}to become ready for use especially by booting a program

et: (senses 1-4) Middle English {it}boten{/it} "to put boots on," derivative of {it}bote, bot{/it} {et_link|boot:3|boot:3}; (sense 5) short for {it}bootstrap{/it} in sense "to perform a bootstrap operation," derivative of {et_link|bootstrap:2|bootstrap:2}
shortdef: to eject or discharge summarily —often used with out

et: Middle English {it}bot, bote{/it} "advantage, good, relief, deliverance, redemption, amends, cure," Old English {it}bōt{/it} "a making good, repair, relief, deliverance, remedy, improvement, atonement, penance, compensation," going back to Germanic {it}*botō{/it} "improvement" {ma}{mat|better:1|}{/ma}

Though its Old and Middle English predecessors were common nouns with numerous senses, {it}boot{/it} now occurs rarely outside of the idiom {it}to boot.{/it} This phrase is attested in the sense "to the advantage (of someone)" in Middle English ("to youre bote") and hence was generalized to "as an extra thing, into the bargain" and then "in addition, moreover."
shortened from {et_link|booty:1|booty:1}, perhaps by association with {et_link|boot:1|boot:1}

dt.t: This steak is {it}as tough as old boots{/it}.
Don't worry about her—she's {it}as tough as old boots{/it}.

dt: {bc}a person who often tells other people what to do {bc}a bossy person

shortdef: a person who often tells other people what to do : a bossy person —often used before another noun

dt: {bc}to treat someone powerful with too much respect in order to get approval

dt.t: He's just the assistant to the manager, there's no need to {it}lick his boots{/it}.

shortdef: to treat someone powerful with too much respect in order to get approval
too confident or proud of oneself
